newsitem.title: USA: Dingell backs SEC probe of "soft dollar" abuses.
newsitem.headline: Dingell backs SEC probe of "soft dollar" abuses.

text.p: House Commerce committee ranking member John Dingell said Thursday he supports the Securities and Exchange Commission's probe into alleged abuses of "soft-dollar" practices.
In a letter to SEC chairman Arthur Levitt, the Michigan Democrat wrote to request a full report of the results of the regulatory agency's examination of the practices.

"Given the significant importance of this issue to the integrity of the markets and your protection of investors, please provide us with a comprehensive report on the results of review of soft-dollar practices," Dingell wrote.

Last month in Tucson, Az., Levitt voiced concerns about brokers paying so-called "soft dollars" to money managers who bring in business -- a practice some call "frequent flyer miles of the brokerage business."
Brokers who provide soft-dollar services typically set aside a percentage of the commissions charged for trades as a credit or rebate that may be used by customers to buy soft dollar services.
Although the practice is not illegal, federal authorities are concerned that fees are not always used to pay for costs associated with investment decisions.

"As you know, soft dollars have become big business (by estimates, $1 billion annually) and abuses have multipled amid growing evidence of harm to the investing public," Dingell wrote in the letter dated February 27.

While Dingell concurs with calls for toughening disclosure rules, he pointed out the SEC last November withdrew a proposal that would have required investment advisers to provide an annual report to clients regarding their soft-dollar practices.
